docs.lead_paragraph: TWO years ago this week, Jeffrey R. Immelt became chairman and chief executive of General Electric. At the close of business on Sept. 10, 2001, Mr. Immelt's first day on the job, G.E.'s stock was at $39.95 a share. It would not trade for another week because the market was closed after the Sept. 11 attacks. The following months were difficult, and the stock fell to as low as $22.48 this year.
docs.abstract: Market Insight interview with General Electric chairman Jeffrey R Immelt; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER his morning class, Richard Greenwald returns to the communal dining room for an elegant lunch of mushroom barley soup and tomato and turkey quiche. Dressed in a black-and-white houndstooth jacket over a dark blue shirt, he greets everyone he meets, seeming very much the big man on campus. Prominent he is, but Joe College he's not. Rather, Mr. Greenwald, 83, lives in Westchester Meadows, a continuing care retirement community in Valhalla, where he is president of the residents' council.

headline.main: A Lot of Life, a Little Help

docs.abstract: Article on rise in number of unusual housing projects for relatively healthy and well-to-do older people that have opened or are under construction in Westchester County, NY; facilities and activities at Westchester Meadows in Valhalla, Fountains at RiverVue in Tuckahoe and other high-end continuing care retirement communities described; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sara McGinn-Shapiro, a daughter of Mary McGinn and Bernard Shapiro of Barrington Hills, Ill., was married yesterday to Samuel Louis Feder, a son of Judith and Stanley Feder of McLean, Va. Rabbi Arthur Bleche officiated at the Black Horse Inn in Warrenton, Va. The Rev. Robert F. Drinan, a Roman Catholic priest and former United States representative, took part in the ceremony. Mrs. Feder, 26, is a financial analyst with Fannie Mae, the mortgage company in Washington. She graduated from the College of William & Mary. Her father is the director of litigation at Prairie State Legal Services, a legal aid organization in Rockford, Ill. Her mother is a deputy general counsel at Allstate Insurance Company in Northbrook, Ill.

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER building his medical practice to nearly 4,000 patients over 18 years, Dr. Nick Fitterman, an internist in Huntington, has decided to start scaling back. Last month, he made the formal transition, and on Sept. 1, he began seeing only those patients who paid a $1,500 annual retainer. Four hundred patients have signed up, forgoing the usual insurance reimbursements but becoming what Dr. Fitterman calls ''participants in a long-term wellness plan.'' The patients can have unlimited appointments at no additional cost, same-day or next-day appointments and what his brochure calls ''unhurried'' visits. Dr. Fitterman also promises he will keep his beeper on and answer phone calls around the clock, seven days a week. He has even begun making house calls again.

headline.main: For $1,500 Retainer, the Doctor Will See You Now

docs.abstract: Article on Dr Nick Fitterman, internist in Huntington, NY, who, seeking to scale back from nearly 4,000 patients, begins seeing only those patients who pay $1,500 annual retainer; 400 patients, forgoing usual insurance reimbursement, have signed up for 'long-term wellness plan'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John Edwards, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, cannot pass a crowd these days without talking about his father the millworker or growing up in rural North Carolina. For Richard A. Gephardt, the campaign stories are about his father the milk truck driver and his son's successful battle with prostate cancer. But spend a day with Howard Dean and it is almost as if his life began the day he stepped behind the governor's desk in Vermont 12 years ago. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman is far more animated talking about the intricacies of trade policy than in sharing stories about growing up in Stamford, Conn.

headline.main: Political Memo; Democrats Split on Pushing The Personal or the Political

docs.abstract: Striking stylistic divide emerges among Democratic presidential hopefuls as they struggle to determine extent to which they should focus on their personal lives in building candidacies; Sen John Edwards and Rep Richard Gephardt, both from meager beginnings, stress personal details, while Howard Dean and Sen Joseph Lieberman focus on their political accomplishments; some believe that divulging intimate details gives voters more complete picture, while others fear they will be accused of exploitation and that too many personal details will divert voters' attention from important issues; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The state Motor Vehicle Commission, which is trying to combat fraud, has begun requiring multiple identification documents from people applying for and renewing drivers' licenses. Under the new requirements, New Jersey residents have to provide several forms of identification that add up to six points in order to obtain a license. Different forms of identification, like passports, current drivers' licenses, birth certificates, high school diplomas and health insurance cards, with varying point values, are among the many types of documents that will be honored. New digital licenses with bar codes and digital photos will be issued starting this winter. Drivers renewing their licenses will no longer be able to do so by mail. Karen DeMasters
docs.abstract: New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission, seeking to combat fraud, begins requiring multiple identification documents from people applying for and renewing driver's licenses (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: He is the other show-biz Arnold running for governor of California -- the poorer, smaller one. But even more than his movie-star counterpart, he is a prisoner of make-believe, a captive of a freakish body, a man trapped inside a character, the punch line to his own life. This candidate, Gary Coleman, 35, portrayed Arnold Jackson, the cute little black boy who was taken in by a wealthy white man on the 70's sitcom ''Diff'rent Strokes.'' By the last episode, he was an 18-year-old still pretending to be 12.

headline.main: Here's the Rest of Me, Another Californian Says

docs.abstract: Actor Gary Coleman says his race for California governor is aimed at getting people to recognize that he is adult with man-sized ideas despite his child-sized body, interview; says he will stay in race to end; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee has opened an investigation into allegations of wrongdoing at Tenet Healthcare and requested yesterday that the company produce a large number of documents for the inquiry. In a letter to Trevor Fetter, the acting chief executive of Tenet, Senator Charles E. Grassley, the committee's chairman, criticized Tenet as a company with a ''sordid corporate history'' that had repeatedly fallen into scandal.

headline.main: Senate Finance Committee Demands Tenet Documents

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee opens inquiry into allegations of wrongdoing at Tenet Healthcare and requests company produce large number of documents for probe; committee chairman Sen Charles E Grassley, in letter to Tenet's acting chief executive Trevor Fetter, criticizes Tenet as company with 'sordid corporate history' that has repeatedly fallen into scandal; adds 'Tenet appears to be corporation that is ethically and morally bankrupt'; most of requests for documents and other information pertain to Tenet's hospital in Redding, Calif, its cardiology program has been accused of providing medically unnecessary tests and surgery; Tenet spokesman Harry Anderson says company plans to cooperate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbying here is often about the little things a few choice words whispered in a few choice ears. That certainly was the case this year for Craig L. Fuller, a former White House official who lobbies for the nation's big drugstore chains, as Congress drafted legislation on a Medicare drug benefit. For years, Mr. Fuller urged his membership to oppose every such bill. But this year he decided that passage of a drug benefit was inevitable.
docs.abstract: Article in series Re-Examing Medicare focuses on efforts by National Association of Chain Drug Stores to pass legislation on Medicare drug benefit, something association has opposed in past; key rivals to drug store chains are benefit managers such as Medco and AdvancePCS, whose plans cover most workers and can bypass retail chains via mail-order; association's president Craig L Fuller says his group's crucial objective is ensuring that patients can continue to buy drugs at their local pharmacies; photo (M)
